documents.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
documents.content: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that enables computers to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed. It focuses on developing algorithms that can learn patterns from data.

documents.title: Vector Databases Explained
documents.content: Vector databases are specialized databases designed to store and query high-dimensional vectors efficiently. They use advanced indexing techniques like HNSW or IVF to enable fast similarity search operations.

documents.title: Natural Language Processing Fundamentals
documents.content: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a field of AI that focuses on enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language. Key techniques include tokenization, part-of-speech tagging, and semantic analysis.

documents.title: Neural Network Architectures
documents.content: Neural networks are computing systems inspired by biological neural networks. Common architectures include feedforward networks, convolutional neural networks (CNNs), and recurrent neural networks (RNNs).

documents.title: Semantic Search vs Keyword Search
documents.content: Semantic search understands the intent and context behind queries, going beyond simple keyword matching. It uses embeddings and vector similarity to find content that is conceptually related rather than just lexically similar.

documents.title: Large Language Models
documents.content: Large Language Models (LLMs) are transformer-based models trained on vast amounts of text data. They can generate human-like text, answer questions, and perform various language tasks. Examples include GPT, BERT, and T5.

documents.title: Embedding Techniques
documents.content: Text embeddings convert words, sentences, or documents into dense vector representations. Popular techniques include Word2Vec, GloVe, and contextual embeddings from transformer models like BERT.

documents.title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation
documents.content: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) combines the strengths of retrieval systems and generative models. It retrieves relevant information from a knowledge base and uses it to generate more accurate and contextual responses.

queries.text: How do machine learning algorithms work?
What are the best databases for storing embeddings?
